reviewText:
My Review of Dawn of Fantasy: Kingdom Wars

It should be noted I do not review a game unless it is very good or very bad, in this case it is exceptionally good.

Its almost as if the game was made by people who actually play games!

This is not really an MMORTS, and those die hard fans of the MMORTS genre will likely be a bit dissapointed but don't let that hold you back. Essentially this game is a single player game with multiplayer matchmaking. You develop your humble little hamlet all the way to a thriving medeviel metropolis, micromanaging each detail along the way. At least until you get familiar with the MANY shortcuts the game has to offer, for those people not interested in examining each element of your lemmings life. For those who do, however the game rewards you! One example of this is in your main city, creating a more efficient system for gold to be mined, will actually help more than just clicking on your lemmings (peasants) and telling them to mine gold.

There is no shortage of depth in this game, while you may indeed find it a bit lonely I think you will easily discover (as is typical) the long list of NPC questions will give you a more roleplay" (or if you are a hipster
date: "immersion") value with go for a very long time.\n\nTrue to it's boast this game is not a play to win game

reviewText:
Kingdom wars is not only an RTS with in-depth leveling system on units, it is an MMO. The ability to co-op seige npc towns to gain bonus resources and crowns (used for upgrading technologies, and advanced units) is remarkable.

Combat system - Each group of soldiers has a number of units inside it, and as long as 1 lives the entire group can be healed. The abilities of each group of soldiers also come with abilities which help in the midst of battle, some are more defensive abilities while others can deal heavy damage or movement speed in tough situations. In all the combat is well rounded with units that counter other units, and ways to win if strategically done.

Building and Resources - This game is not a win in 1 day game, it takes patients and time to succeed into being a king. The resource gathering is per minute, which draws the building out but is worth it. During the time it takes to raise walls and gather resources for other builds you can spend time doing the Unlimited quests in the game for Crowns (In-game currency). Each building takes time, but you can build it all at once if you have the resources for it, or if you become impatient on a nessecary building you can rush the build with Crowns.

Questing - The game has unlimited quests, this gives you a never-ending pve aspect to a largely pvp game. From Quests you recieve Crowns, and/ Resources. Some quests are very challenging but with co-op quests it notifies you that you can get assistance doing the quest (either from a random player, or from a friend off of your friendslist).

PVE - I enjoy the pve the most. The battles in each of the zones is different, elvens fought in elven zones, humans in human zones, and orc's in the orc zones. Beyond that there are zones not allocated to a race. These zones have harder creatures to fight like orges (a unit of the orc's but the entire zone is ogre's), Dwarfs (a style of unit bought with crowns), goblins (another unit of the orc's but the entire zone is goblins), and even an extremely hard zone of Dragons!

PVP - The pvp is setup as matchmaking, you will never fight someone much bigger then your army/town and you will never be able to pick on the weak. Its balanced so that you can enjoy fighting without the fear of being slaughtered. If you choose not to fight a player who is trying to fight you then you can do a payout" option and sacrifice some resources or a few units to not have to battle them and it allows you to return to what you what to do (Quest
hoursPlayed: etc).\n\nNot pay to win - I want to state that in no way is this a pay to win game. There is options for buying packages
voteText: and being a Premium account but it gives only crowns
helpfulPercent: resources
votesHelpful: and a bonus daily reward for premium accounts. These are all things you can aquire very easily in game but by buying a package you are not spending 30+ minutes gathering the resources or farming the crowns. Buying premium not only saves you time gathering crowns
votesTotal: it also helps the game grow and gives incentive to play. As a closing statement to this i will repeat - Its not pay to win
votesFunny: its free to play. Buying only helps you grow faster and helps the game grow faster.\n\nIn all I must recommend this game to anyone who enjoys RTS games
commentsCount: this breaks the mold of what RTS use to be and brings a new light on the future of RTS. I have enjoyed every aspect of the game and hope to see more content in the future."
column16: October 30, 2014

reviewText: Kingdom Wars is a fairly decent city builder. You start out small and slowly build up your kindom, which is instanced, and eventually start sending your hero and army out in to the world. There is interaction and PvP with other players and players can invade your kingdom. I enjoyed building my kingdom and doing the castle seiges. Anyways, if you enjoy RTS and online play then you will probably enjoy this game.

This is a great game that takes concepts from Middle ages and takes it to another level.
Fun to play and most of the time nice rewards for comming back to the game.
If you are in to Real-Time Strategy games that lead to a lot of fun to play and give some epic wars, this is one of those better games.
There is still a lot to do for making the game more playable for a larger public, but devs are active or at least seems to be active :P
For this money, just enjoy the game and hope that some better changes will follow!
Have FUN with it! (personal i prefere the single player, multi seems to be a bit buggy in bigger battles).
(my score : 8/10 for the first game - 7/10 for the second like it is now).
And thats an honnest score for hours of fun!

reviewText:
At first, this seemed like a good idea. Still is a good idea. But, poorly executed in my opinion.

Some issues I ran into:
- While the tutorial covers how to play as the humans, I tried playing as the elves. Must have been playing for 2 hours before I figured out how to add additional buildings. Not at all clear.
- The text in the game is an odd mix of old-english and modern. Threw me off quite a bit.
- The elven language uses a lot of custom words and lexicon. But they don't explain what many of the words mean, and you have to figure it out from the contex of the conversation.
- Tooltips for the upgrades referenced other upgrades that I could not locate.
- Graphical problems. The game would freeze randomly. Sometimes the game would suddenly flip back and forth between day and night multiple times over a few seconds. Turning down my graphics settings didn't seem to help.

These are just a few of the issues I had.

reviewText:
Okay, I'm going to explain the good and the bad about this game. Keep in mind that this is my first review.

The bad: You cannot manuelly place buildings, they are all automatic. If you're hoping to leave your workers to gain resources for you while your offline then you'll be terribly mistaken, while offline you gain 50% less resources than you did before. The game is terribly buggy, Some units walk across the sky in sieges, some walk over mountains and the pathfinding is not that great. The AI are some of the worse I've ever seen; While doing a custom siege I sent my reinforcements to attack the army that was besieging me and after they killed my reinforcements what did they do? they stood there for the next 45 mins doing nothing when my castle was rype for the taking. Some of your troops wont attack certain troops when they're standing right in front of them unless you right click on them to attack. The game also has a terrible learning curve and you will ofen get bored playing this game. You WILL spend most of your time in the world map traveling between cities and to new strongholds to attack. Also when starting off in southmont players can attack your townhall from outside your double layered walls and immediately win the battle since battles are won by destroying the town hall, not the army nor the city. The town hall. Mods are also usually never on, I've never seen one on anyways or one that would actaully do something productive and help players.

The good: PVP is fun. Sieges are fun and battles in general are fun. The storylines are decent. Though you cannot manuelly place buildings it is always nice to finish your city and admire its beauty. Theres also a nice little shop that you can spend crowns on to get special units or more resources. Crowns can be rewarded to you through attacking other players or doing quests or by buying them. You also require crowns to build walls.

I played 12 hours into this game, so before you haters say I didn't play the game enough then think again. I played 12 hours into this game and i listed all the things i could think of and most of those things are bad. This game may be for some but it's not for everyone. If you can get past all the things listed above then this game might just be for you. 5/10. Im not the best at giving ratings.

reviewText:
Kingdom Wars, a fantasy RPG game based around 3 races, the Elves, Humans and Orcs. This game is an ''Open-World'' RTS with RPG Elements here and there, with a great execution on Mass-Battles it can be kind of unbalanced here and there, in PvP for example if you have a highly trained army of 25 people you will be easily killed by a weak army of 10 units. The game still requires alot of scaling in many different aspects but the developer team which by the way exists out of only four people who are working very hard to provide you the best possible RTS game they can make out of this.

Gameplay,
the gameplay aspect of this game is still wonky and outbalanced by bugs or mistakes in the ''Scaling'' system but overall it is still a solid part of this game and most ''Hardcore-RTS'' players will be able to look past it. This game is  not very competitive because of a simple mechanic called: Battle protection. It allows you to not get attacked by anyone at all for a long time. In most FTP RTS games the Battle Protection timer continues even when you are Offline, but in KW
Battle Protection pauses removing the Competitive aspect of this game by a lot. Luckily though, you can never be matched against an army bigger than your own. After some mishaps here and there and unbalanced features the gameplay is still solid and since it will most likely be improved in future updates it isn't such a big issue. I give the gameplay in this game a 6/10. Which will most likely become an 8/10 or a 9/10 if they fix these issues.

The biggest problem in this game so far are the graphics and the countless bugs that keep appearing, while this may sound like a stupid thing to say, in this case it really isn't. The resolution in this game is incredibly low, I have seen games from back in 2001 that look better than Kingdom Wars. And Kingdom Wars was made in 2010. The bugs though are far worse than the Graphics. People are constantly reporting in that they crash during Sieges or that they bought something with real money and didn't get what they bought an even bigger issue is that the resource counter doesn't work. For example, sometimes I make 10 food per minute and 95 wood per minute and then 10 minutes later I make 29.9 food per minute and 63.5 wood per minute, the Resource counter is by far the biggest issue. Small things like this can be quite irritating at times but it is also to be expected from a WIP game and will most likely be fixed eventually.

Cons include:

-Outdated graphics
-Several unbalanced gameplay elements
-Lots of bugs
-Huge amount of dialogue can be a bit overwhelming at times

However this may sound negative, the pros in this case outnumber and outscale the cons by far. Pros like:

-Solid gameplay
-Lots of detailed lore
-Frequent updates usually containing lots of bug fixes
-An ever growing, non-toxic and friendly community
-Great and active staff members
-And most importantly, NOT pay2win

This game has a lot of potential. As long as the developers get rid of bugs and expands upon its pros, this game will have a bright future ahead of it.

reviewText:
Dawn of Fantasy features both Online PvP play as well as a few single player modes more geared to the casual player. Single Player mode is broken up into three sub-sections; Lay Siege is a quick jump in and play random scenario that starts the player with a squadron of troops and siege weapons (such as Belfries and Trebuchets) in a basic camp just outside the enemy fortress .The goal is to invade the enemy fortress break open the main gate and kill the king. There is only one wave to play in lay Siege and the outcomes does not affect your save file Homelands.


Next we have Castle Defense, a little more involved, where players instead are given a hometown with peasants,soldiers,and walls. Tower upgrades, many archers, and spike traps are key to surviving the long siege as wave upon wave of enemy troops march towards your castle front. One problem with this mode is that the enemy troops swarm up by their target gate but do not move out-of-the-way for the battering rams to do their job. Soldiers don’t break in, siege weapons stand around, in fact everyone stands around slowly getting picked off by a single battalion of archers perched within the final keep. Even when the next wave arrives the only rip apart what they can easily access. Again all spoils go to no one after victory/defeat is declared.



Lastly for single player there is the Kingdoms mode. This is like a campaign but more open ended. It uses the World Map but with less instruction than the Online Kingdom provides. And instead of quests and tutorials players are given an expected battle every few minutes regardless of progress made. The goal of this mode is to conquer the entire World Map without your Hometown being captured by the enemy forces. This is in my experience the hardest part of the game,and if you are new to the game and confused on how the world map works, don’t fret, it is explained in the Online Kingdom mode, the main mode of the game,which is next.

The Online Kingdom mode is a go-at-your own pace experience that guides players through a story based on the player’s selected Kingdom. This game differs from the single player games because it revolves around taking armies out from your hometown and bringing them to the World Map so that they can travel to other towns and quest locations. Other towns give means of trade, buying mercenaries, training units to do other jobs; and in a pinch acting as a place holder for precious units when the town population cap(s) are full. Swapping between the two perspectives, world map and town, is the vital key to Dawn of Fantasy’s uniqueness.

Along with all the mechanics introduced in the other modes, this one has an extra influence resource known as crowns that can be used to buy other resources,speed up building constructions, and most importantly buy special units such as dragons and Dwarven fighters. For $9.99 you can buy 120 crowns which grants one the option to purchasing the Royal Dragon, the most powerful unit in the game. Unlike the Kingdom’s Mode of single player, battles are engaged at the pace of the player. The image below is a swarm of Orc Riders actually waiting to speak with my towns hero before deciding to attack my precious colony.



With all these gameplay modes spending an hour or two building armies and raising an effective economy is quite easy. Units are created in squads of multiple members. Instead of training one peasant for 180 food the game actually trains 5 little guys on the screen, same goes for infantry. Despite these 5 little workers being spawned the towns’ population is only increased by 1 for doing this. Building houses also increases the total population cap by 1, making a booming economy a very long-term goal. Paradoxically, gathering times for resources in Dawn of Fantasy  are a slower than some may find comfortable. This is to encourage the World Map exploration and trade, as well as looting the dead corpses with peasants for that extra economic boost. Erecting buildings requires no peasants, but takes on average an hour to complete without the use of any crowns.

Presentation of the game has a few minor bugs in it as well. Some background cameras in town menus do not stay on course and can be spastic. Leaving your mouse on a button can provide information, but it does not help when the information box is in front of another button. The ticker above head saying the resources gathered per minuet is also inaccurate, and will not update even when there are peasants collecting a resource .

Despite these few hiccups the game itself is a treat to play. The camera controls are well done, same can be said about the speech banks. Unlike Age of Empires, the characters in-game actually say what needs your attention, instead of the sound cues you has to learn about through multiple session will not disappear Dawn of Fantasy is a game filled with hours of gameplay for the strategist waiting to capture castles and rule a world of fantasy. The PvP options now are for the competitive player mostly, because you cannot share resources with other player in-game, however alliances in a multiplayer game .

reviewText:
This game is a lot of fun... at first.

It's a fantasy based real time strategy game with a surprisingly good interlacing story for each of the three factions. The free-to-play model is actually very good and isn't as pay-to-win as some people claim, especially since they added a hard-limit to how many crowns (the in-game currency needed to buy the most powerful upgrades/units) you can buy with gold.

You can take control of dragons. O.o

If you're clever, you can thrive in this game very quickly. PvP is.. fairly balanced but it feels like an afterthought. What stinks is that the game almost forces you to co-op if you want to take large NPC cities as you only have 30mins to complete a seige.

I really, really want to give this game a thumbs up because it IS a lot of fun and has a ton of potential BUT it is absolutely plagued by bugs. You will most likely rage quit the first time you spend 25 mins trying to take a city and the game crashes.. which happens OFTEN. Armies and units will get stuck and you might have to start over entirely. Controls lack finesse. Ehh.. if you're reading this and love fantasy RTS games, feel free to give the game a try but expect a few technical difficulties.

reviewText: Kingdom Wars is a amazing title to play if you are into the rts genre. Taking the scale of the total war series and stronghold games it is a game you are sure to play for hours. My inicial recations and thoughts on the game were that it would be a pay to win players dream, but this was not the case. Like many F2P games out there paying only gets you cosmetics that have no greater purpose. The ingame economy system is also well balanced with limatations to just how much you can acheive. Based around four main resource types and crowns, the harder to earn currency, you'll have a fun time trying to arrange your workers into such a way to balacnce it out. Another strong point in this game is the graphics and model textures. For being made by a realtively small company the game is very well looking with some much going on at once with minmal to no lag what-so-ever. Going off of graphics they have a very sound sound engine (pun intended) that has very realistic effects and ambience.\n\nNow no game is perfect, this game does have a few bugs now and then, but nothing gamebreaking. The devs and mods are on all the time with their fanbase and players supporting and helping when they can. It can also be a little on the hard to run side if your computer is a little on the lower side. With the amount and time the devs put in this game can only get better in the future.

reviewText: I personally like Kingdom Wars a lot. First of all I have to say this ISN'T pay to win. I think people saying that didn't understood the game at all. Everything is achievable through gameplay for everyone, only payable items are pure estetics, also the premium just gives a speed boost in certain ways, it is for example like buying an exp boost on league of legends, you just go faster, not better. I repeat, this is a free game, so you can't blame people who use the premium, you can get the full gameplay without it. Guys spending money, are just helping the devs and the game getting better and bigger, is that a bad thing? That said, the game is great, I see a lot of potential. Yes, there are some bugs (what game has no bugs?) and the devs are awesome in fixing them as fast as possible. Just try the game and see yourself, it is free.\nI really hope new players will come, this game truly deserves it.

reviewText:
Español:
Tengo que admitir que no me esperaba mucho de este juego, que sería algo tan simple como construir y matar. Pero estaba equivocado ... llevo pocos días de juego y me está encantando. Simplificándolo mucho, podría decirse que es una mezcla de un juego de navegador, tipo Ikariam/ogame, y un total war, para las batallas.
Es un juego donde tienes que esperar X tiempo para conseguir recursos, unidades, etc ... combinado con batallas en tiempo real a gran escala. Además de una buena diplomacia incluida, buen transfondo y multijugador. Entre otras cosas. Haciendo que la gestión de cada raza sean completamente diferentes entre sí, además del estilo de juego.

Es un tipo de juego que jamás había visto y que no me esperaba que me gustase tanto. Es algo nuevo, una corriente de aire fresco.



English:
I have to admit I was not expecting much from this game, it would be something as simple as building and kill. But I was wrong ... took a few days and I am loving the game. In simplified terms, one could say that is a mixture of a browser game, Ikariam / ogame type, and a total war, for battle.
It is a game where you have to wait X time for resources, units, etc ... combined with battles in real time scale. In addition to good diplomacy included, great backdrop and multiplayer. Among other things. Making the management of each race are completely different, besides the gameplay.

It is a type of game I'd ever seen and I was not expecting that I liked so much. It's something new, a breath of fresh air.

reviewText:
I bought the game about 2 years ago.  Back when they had the cash shop.  Although some poeple felt that it was pay to win, it was not in the least bit since I never spent a dime on it and still was able to pve and pvp without problems.  Still to this day now that it's F2P, you still don't have to pay for anything since your armies are always matched with people of similar armies.  It's a really good way of handeling a cash shop.  If you don't want to pay any money, you will have to learn how to play is all, which isn't a bad thing.

It was a buggy game when I first got a hold of it, as most newish games, and that did deter me for about 4 months.  After a while they had a few patches that made it less laggy for me and that's when I started racking up the hours, Building more cities, destroying more foes, and gathering those crowns for more armies.  I grew up playing RTS games, Age of Empires was my first multiplayer game, and I played that for a couple of years along with Empire earth when it came out.  This has strong elements of your typical RTS, but it has so much more.  Long term cities, taking over NPC towns, exploring the map, questing, and co-op sieging just to name a few great things that seperate it from your standard RTS.

I had so much fun that I invited a few friends to play with me and after teaching them how to play we were pillaging empires left and right.  When you play with friends, it usually makes a game that much more fun.  You invite friends, your friends invite friends, etc..  Soon you can start an alliance with people you know that you will get along with.  Although you can only 2v1 vs AI, and 1v1 in pvp, hopefully later in the games life they can expand that.   Good times were spent on sieging cities with a friend.

I wasn't too interested in the MMO part of this game at first, I had played world of warcraft for about 2 years back in 2008, and grew out of it, but this game fits right in and youre not overpowerd by MMO nerds sitting on a ♥♥♥♥ bucket and trying to hit on a night elf.   I grew up playing age of empires, empire earth, and starcraft.  Although this game isnt on the same level, it's still tons of fun.  More of a long term RTS.

Since I bought the game, fast forward to today, Reverie has had many great patches that improved the game immensely, and with the launch of their FtP model, it's better than ever.  New units, new buildings, better performance, vassels, and unit balencing (and that's just the tip of the iceberg)

Also, I have a guide on my profile for new players to get some all arounds tips for the game.

9/10  Unique, fun, cheap, and helpful devs/mods.  Would buy again.

reviewText: I have been playing this game for the last few weeks.  I was so excited about this game in my first day, that I draged 5 of my friends to play this game.  With any game you find what you like and don't like.  What sets this game off for me is, its what I expect an MMORTS to be!  When friends of mine ask me, whats the game like or how to compare it.  I tell them that this is a unique game, then I tell them I can help them learn.  I personly found the game easy to learn and so did my friends.  The game is complex to get you very excited, but not difficult by any means.  The game runs smooth on the graphics and is very appealing to the eyes.  Yet of course my favorite thing of all about this game however is the building of my own castle and how I want to build my army, hoping for more styles of castle and land layouts down the road!  So would I recommend this game to anyone, yes deffenitely!  Even if you don't care for  the multiplayer aspect or your not a true rts fan, give this game a whirl, I bet you'll find something you highly enjoy about Kingdom Wars.

reviewText:
This game is a very unike and good game.im going to be listing the good factore about these games and the rating of each section

Combat- 7/10 the combat in this game is very good, but is still sort of buggy. sometimes during the combat you dont even see the soliders swinging their swords or anything, but the descriptions of each troop stating their weaknesses and stregths actually take place in the conbat. overall i think the combat has a lot of potential, but lacks a bit. it is definitly the only weakness of this game

graphics-7/10 as we know this game was released in 2013 but the graphics arent bad for a free game. im not too sure how this game company profits off this amazing game becuase you can really see that a lot of time and money went into this game, but it is still free. the graphics in this game are bummy in some areas, but are pretty good overall

Strategy-9/10 this game requires a lot of brains and time to be successful. it is a very slow game to progress through (i got 10 hours and i still dont have walls) but it makes it very realistic, this isnt like a game where everything happens and its very quick. however when you do spend money it speeds up this process, which is obviously intended so the company can make profit,

Multiplayer-10/10 this game has an amazing multiplayer layout. you can send your friends resorces, do campaign with them, and fight with them. To me the multiplayer is pretty straight foreward, and i wouldnt change a thing about it.

Difficult- 9/10 Im going to admit, this game is VERY difficult. your troops die pretty easily and its not easy to get precious resorces like wood stone gold or food. by building a wide variety of building, it eats up all of them. this is where the money spenders come in and get a free run to succession

overall i would STRONGLY recommed this game due to the fact that it is free and is AMAZING, and i would pay for this game any day. this game is a mix of banished,mount and blade, and stronghold crusader. if i were you i would get my hands on this before the developers put a price on this. i hope this helped you make you decision:)

reviewText: This game is excellent for all of those people who are dying for a patient, Non-Pay2win game. Kingdom Wars is like the Total War Series + the Age of Empires Series. What I love about this game is that there are 3 Factions that are playable, the Humans, the Orcs, and the Elves, each with its own unique strengths. There is also a conquerable map that has little settlements that have their very own, very detailed lore. This game is also not a frustrating Pay2win game, although, there is a special currency called influence that you may buy with real money, and the currency is needed to grow your Empire, it is not that hard to get though. There are many ways to get this special currency, one way is to log in everyday and debate whether to claim Influence or the Random item, another way to get Influence would be to battle with other players. The Community so far seems very nice and so far I've not met many people who want to make you have a bad time while playing. The game offers very fun challenges that really are challenging! So far, I am having a blast playing, I've been very addicted to this game and ever want to pull my eyes off the screen, I'd highly reccomend this game to your friends!

reviewText:
Funny Total War like game with RPG elements and Browser games elements.
It's no more P2W but it has marginal Pay2Progress elements.
Devs keep upgrading the game nearly every week and try to improve the game further and further.

One Problem that this game has is that creating formations with your units is a bit messy because the unitcontrol system is not a powerful tool.
It is very hard to march forward in a specific formation or place your units in the right order on the battlefield.
And the Hold the Ground" order is really buggy and not working perfect.
That is something that should be improved.

A other Problem is that single units can be too strong. Something that defentily should be fixed.

The last problem is
date:
is that the AI is extremly passive. You can lure enemy AI units one by one out and kill them.
It is possible to conquer a whole fortress with very few units.

But this game is still great and has alot potential.
There is no other game like this out there."

reviewText:
Update: 11/11/2014: The game has gone through a major change  including unit stat rebalance. I will play again and  amend the review accordingly.

This is my first review and its very basic please bear this in mind.

I have been following this game for a long time... Including the beta period and prior to steam release. The game has a very intresting storyline and RTS mechanics, however it lacks in social connectivity and player engagement with one another.

After you have reached a certain stage of the game, there is no endgame content to try and you feel like there is nothing further challange.

The difficuclty and balance is scewed for some units and PVP/Co-OP is completely broken as there is no logical reason why two armies of the same size cannot co-op.

It seems to be a dice roll issue or some back end server configuration issue.

However if they can fix the PVP and CO-OP issues and add some meaningful endgame conten such as Guild versus Guild and more player interaction with one another. this game could get  alot of its community back.

At the moment the most number of users online at one time is in 10s. Hopefully when the above issues are resolved the community will grow and bring back some flare to the end game content.

reviewText:
- Is this game fun?
- Yes.  Its one of those games were you throw it on for abit, do some stuff then switch it off to come back tomorrow to           more troops, resources, etc. Constant quests will be given so you'll be busy unless you have to siege, which later on you will be doing a lot.  Battles can scale from a small skrimish to full on siege with a wide selection of troops, monsters, war machines, heros, dragons , etc.  Though choosing your battles is the most important because you can be quickly overwhelmed and overrunned.

- Is this bad?
- In some areas, yes. Combat is very clunky and fights are one big bloody orgy at most.(Blood for the Blood god!!) That and most units if left unchecked will run around chasing god knows what and probably die. Mostly peasants which you'll be lossing left and right when exploring or fighting. No real tatics in open battles or quests. Just send your army in one direction and loot the dead  as they go.(This isn't Total War guys). It comes down to who has more numbers though the more veterans you have the better for you or it can worst because a high level unit of knights can 3 v 1 and win. Seiges you have to plan or you will loss your army fast and retreating is, at times more costly. So once you start theres no going back. Units only rout during quest's so don't expect units to ♥♥♥♥ themselves when 3 dragons burn down a whole castle.

- Factions?
- Puny 'umans
- Dem pointy ear'd elve boyz.
- And da best of all, da Orkz! WAAAAAAAAAAGH!

- Is this game pay to win like most MMO's?
- No. Its there but IT CAN be avoided completely. Daily rewards can help in some areas depending on what you get. Plus quests often give you tons of loot, crowns, food, troops, etc. The store is there but name one MMO out there that doesn't have a store. Plus if you do want to sink some money into this game it's really cheap. The most expensive thing is about $30 bucks.  Which isn't bad for what you get out of it.

- Should I try this?
- If you like Fantesy games and city management games, try this. And for ♥♥♥♥ sake this game is free so you're not spending a cent on it. If you liked Stronghold(The orginal, not the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ones) and would like more city management then this a game for you.

reviewText:
Update: 11/11/2014: The game has gone through a major change  including unit stat rebalance. I will play again and  amend the review accordingly.

This is my first review and its very basic please bear this in mind.

I have been following this game for a long time... Including the beta period and prior to steam release. The game has a very intresting storyline and RTS mechanics, however it lacks in social connectivity and player engagement with one another.

After you have reached a certain stage of the game, there is no endgame content to try and you feel like there is nothing further challange.

The difficuclty and balance is scewed for some units and PVP/Co-OP is completely broken as there is no logical reason why two armies of the same size cannot co-op.

It seems to be a dice roll issue or some back end server configuration issue.

However if they can fix the PVP and CO-OP issues and add some meaningful endgame conten such as Guild versus Guild and more player interaction with one another. this game could get  alot of its community back.

At the moment the most number of users online at one time is in 10s. Hopefully when the above issues are resolved the community will grow and bring back some flare to the end game content.

reviewText:
I've been looking for a game that melds a lot of features from some of my favourite strategy games into an online environment, a game that is set aside from others within the same genre, and this really is it. The game is not pay to win and is paced really well, it's not slow nor is it fast, you really feel rewarded from what you receive through the steady rate of progression. The quests help to push you in the right direction while you're starting out, and after just a few hours you'll be making some really steady progress toward the more end-game options.

Positives: As mentioned previously, the game is not pay to win, finding a game like this that is both enjoyable, f2p, and not pay to win seems to be the gaming equivalent of finding gold in your back garden, for this I am very grateful. You have several different options in terms of how you would like to play the game, do you want to be economically focused, do you want to focus on military, etc; this kind of choice makes the game strategically diverse and allows you to shape how you want to play the game, and I felt that this made the game far more enjoyable, especially if you play with friends and work together by taking up different roles.

Negatives: The game is a little buggy right now, and performance can vary. While trying to use the windowed mode feature I found my game crashing very frequently, and I ultimately had to disable that option. I also got stuck in one of the tutorials while trying to access the menu. So the game is definitely in need of some polish. Combat could also do with some work; the current system gets the job done but is quite clunky and very messy. You send your units in and then sit back and hope for the best. Of course the graphics are quite basic but they are bearable, a slight overhaul would be a nice quality of life improvement. A little more direction for players completely new to the genre would also be very useful.

Overall, from my gameplay experience and from the masses of reading I've done about the game, I think it's great and absolutely worth a try. The developers are keen on improving the game and are asking for feedback whenever possible, which really tells me they have their head in the right place.

reviewText:
This game is a unique sort among the strat MMO's. Its tough at first starting out (for humans that is, I am not a fan of Orc or Elven playstyle) but once you get a decent setup the game becomes fairly easy if you can invest time into your economy first before rushing off to pvp and siege.

Pvp however is fairly unbalanced as all the high levels who use their near unkillable lvl 60 hero's and dragons to terrorize lesser players. Though my sound advice for dealing with small minotaur forces and Hero's is massed Crossbows for the humans. Works like a charm.

While there is an ingame micro transaction thing its completely option for customizables, and several booster packs that can only be bought once per city slot, I think this is a fair system compared to other games like battle pirates where its forcing you to constantly spend to stay up to date.

The factions play very differently from one another, Humans play like most fuedal and medieval armies with a large portion of their troops (or as my suggestion goes for) A lot of Halbardier and Archer battalions as they are the cheapest to upgrade at the local training yard, Human siege is rather inaccurate and I would suggest for those dedicated siege armies to bring along 5-10 Treb's or 8 Dwarvern cannons if you have the crowns for them.

I overall give the game a 6.5/10 for soild gameplay, friendly community, nice enough looking graphics.

Though there are quite a few bugs overall besides the occassional resource loss or other minor incident I would recomend this game to my friends.

reviewText:
Kingdom Wars is truly a unique take on the RTS (Real Time Strategy) genre and is truly worth a try for both fans of the genre as well as those new to it.  People who are fans of city-building simulators will also find much to enjoy in this unique title.

While Kingdom Wars has gone through many changes, some good, some less-than-desirable, overall the experience is really something that has to be experienced to understand it.  The very early stages of the game can be somewhat confusing, however it is my understanding that the developers have addressed this issue in the time since I was a new player.

Although there is the option to spend real money (in fact, I obtained my copy of the game back when it was still a regular purchasable title) the game truly is free to play" in the sense that
date: while you can beef up your army using real money purchases
recommended: you will not be penalized for not doing so.  When PvP occurs (which is largely optional) players are matched up roughly based on the strength of their armies.  This is not an absolutely perfect system
hoursPlayed: however it vastly eliminates the possiblity that your opponent will have an absurly stronger army than yours via real money purchases.\n\nAlso
voteText: both the PvP and the PvE aspects of the game are truly exciting and offer an experience not found in other RTS games or titles from other genres.  While similar to PvP
helpfulPercent: the PvE side of the game can be better tailored for those who like a more relaxed approach to playing.\n\nThe thing I like most in the game is the building of one's kingdom
votesHelpful: which is a gradual process that can take weeks or months to expand
votesTotal: depending on your playstyle.  It is really fun to carefully plan your defenses out and try to set up ambushes for would-be attackers
votesFunny: while at the same time it can be very engaging in that you take semi-permanent losses from battles
commentsCount: so you are encouraged to really think things through.  This is the most true for the human race (who specializes in defense) however all of the races
column16: humans
column17: elves and orcs
column18: have an aspect of this.\n\nThe different races play quite differently and I actually have yet to branch out into the orcs and elves
column19: but their playstyles are all unique and offer a vast amount of play time should you choose to explore all three.  Even with only having focused on one race
column20: I have spent many hours on this game and feel like I have only scratched the surface.\n\nThis game has its rough edges
column21: but the developers are serious about making it as polished as can be and have been working hard to make many changes that both improve the gameplay and well as the look and feel of the game.  Bugs have been being addressed over time and overall the game can be played and enjoyed with few interruptions caused by bugs.  The UI (User Interface) could use some attention
column22: however it is still quite functional and usable after some experience with it.\n\nOverall
column23: this game is really fun (which is the most imporant part to many people) and worthy of sinking at least a couple dozen hours into it before deciding if you like it or not.  Do not be fooled by the graphics or the first few minutes of the game - this game is huge and in a very good way."

reviewText:
The f2p model is fair - you get enough to get started and there are no paywalls. There are starter-packs that give a minor boost, but you can't call that pay-to-win at all: the matchmaking is very restrictive.

The AI has bugs that can be cumbersome, but the devs/mods work fast and resolve problems reliably.

The UI is borderline terrible and the build options could really use hotkeys. As you get dragons, that can be disabled by the enemy but not permanently killed, the good outweighs the bad and I can recommend the game.

reviewText:
Interesting game... I will explain.

First off I highly recommend you do the tutorial and actually take the time to read the texts. There is never to much written but there is no voice acting. But the tutorial gives you a lot of needed knowledge to get the hang of the game. Also you might want to start as humans first, the other races, elfs and orcs. have confusing build structures.

Now when it comes to explaining this game I would have to say, it is stronghold kingdoms map combined with a sort of Total war style combat / with age of empires sort of peasantry. Read bellow this for a further explanation.

Stronghold Kingdoms - When in the main world map you will see separate borders. Your settlement will be one of several in a sort of county, with several other faction areas in a province type area. A border separates these which makes it easy to know whose who.

Total War - When it comes to units in this game, you do have large formations of units instead of single soldier running about. When you construct a unit 20 come out inside of one. So when you enter war or move your units to investigate a camp, you will have the different archers in their group, soldiers, knights, so on.

Age of Empires - When it comes to building structures in this game it feels like Age of Empires. Granted you wont find yourself having the peasants build the buildings, but instead you select an available spot on the ground to construct a building. Now the peasants are used to gather materials around the town area, Gold, Wood, Stone, and food are all the average resources you need to have them gathering.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

Things to know when you start!

- You have a 24 hr peace period, meaning other players cannot attack you until after 24 hours.

- Your selection of traits and plains where you build will decide a lot of stuff. Such as if wood is plentiful (plains area) , if stone is easily accessible (In mountains) , Also lastly is wooded areas (In Forests).

- Doing the quests at the beginning will advance your story line, get you free resources, and decent experience towards the game as well. They are easy and actually very fun to complete.

- This is a Stronghold Kingdoms style rts. Which means buildings will start building slower and slower the more you construct. If you don't want to put much time in a breathing game you may want to steer clear.

- I have done little castle work, besides in the tutorial. My reflection on it though is like a Total War style castle. You build the wall then garrison the unit squads along the walls. You also build single siege weapons to attack the walls, making it easier to maneuver or attack different sections of the walls.

- I did not access the market as of yet, though I clicked on it once to view it. It did seem a bit pay to win, as you purchase crowns like on stronghold kingdoms. Then you use the crowns to get resources , fast building , though it does not seem to allow unit purchase. You can purchase dragons though... not sure how OP they are.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

My Impressions

- Early stages of the game I am enjoying. It feels like Age of Empires as my units charge around to wreck the wicked soldiers and goblins about. Making gold and other resources depends completely on how many peasants you send to that specific resource.

- The late game makes me nervous, I really cannot tell if the game has the system like Stronghold Kingdoms that sort of punishes higher lvl players for attacking lower , newer players. But I guess that will be something we see in a few days if I just get rolled by some troll.

- So far I do like this game, its worth continuing to play and I hope to see the population on the game grow.

reviewText:
An rts and an mmo; great combo, a must have for those out there that love these two genres.
Pros:
Good Economy.
You don't have to be on 24/7 collecting resources it does it for you.
Many buildings and upgrades providing many out comes.
Large Map.
Pvp protection for those that want to just build, and play without getting raided.
Decent Graphics.
Multiple Factions and areas to choose from.
Political system.
Cool Medieval soundtrack.
etc.....

Cons:
Some of units may not follow a group when ordered to go to a location.
A little bit of pay to win but you can still do everything it justs takes a little longer.
Other modes such as skrimish or single player campaign you have to buy.
Units cluster which generally turn in to mosh pits.
Animations need lots of work.


7.5/10

This is my review as of 03/11/2014

reviewText: Kingdom Wars was just another free game that i would browse past when i was searching for a new game to play, but when i saw that it had recently come out on steam i decided to take a look. As i saw the trailer for the game it had only peaked my interest more, so i downloaded the game.(best decision ever~) Once the game had finished, i booted it up with no problem and was brought to one of many dream games that i had been searching for! It had conquest in a way that other strategy games could only hope for, but the games that could achieve that level were no where near as Kingdom Wars. This game was well thought out and the graphics are perfect for this kind of game(due to huge ♥♥♥ armies and monsters filling your screen) runs pretty damn well on a laptop. all in all, im hooked, im in love, and i got to stick a sword in another lord's face.  Reverie World Studios i salute. (now if you excuse me there are couple of traitors that need to be decapitated and armies to repel, come Fred, we must hasten back to Black Rock.

reviewText: This game is amazing. You run an entire kingom that you build from the ground up. While there are still bugs that you will encounter, i give this game 5/5 stars for what it is.  If you want to tactically command an army, just as a king would lead his men in to battle back in the mideval ages, this game is for you. It's a game that doesn't go too easy on you either. There is always a new challenge due to the PVP system. The trading system in this game works just as you would think too. Send trade carts, and send troops to protect them from other hostiles, risk your resources, and be rewarded for being smart.

reviewText:
Kingdom Wars is a massive mltiplayer Real Time Strategy game without the concept of pay to play, and in my opinion, it's a really neat game.
First, the visuals are very nice and quite smooth and give more flavour to the medieval atmosphere of the game.
Second, the game is very user-friendly: When you first choose the race and location and all of the details of the city you want to manage, the game makes sure to explain every single option and give the benefits of each side chosen. Also, the game makes sure to help the player as much as it can by having an option to contact directly to the creator, and giving a well-planned tutorial line of quests and a 24 hour protection (that counts ONLY when you're online) which I personally love.
Third, It's just fun! You can customize the looks of your town, build a powerful army and siege all of your opponents' citis, striking fear into their eyes! Also, the NPCs are very entertaining and the game in general gives you a great expirience while playing.

My final point: The game is great, and it's free so if you have the time and will you should DEFINATLY give it a shot. You won't regreat it. (and if you will, don't worry. The community is very helpful and the developers are open for suggestions at any time, so you can help them to make the game better! :D)

reviewText: Finnaly, a game that is good and not pay to win. It's about time. The game is amazing and easy to start of. The game gives you daily rewards each day which makes it easy to get more stuff if your stuck. I haven't played for very long but it is very fun. One suggestion though, can you make it so that bandits spawn in your village more frequently. it is very slow for me to get stuff and i like being able to send out the worker people and get gold from it. So this is why i advise this game for people who do not like p2w and, also like Rts games. I run a pretty bad computer and havent had to change the video settings so even if you think your computer is really bad just try it.

reviewText: So at first i didn't know what to think about this game. And i have to say i was suprised of how fun and addicting the game was.  The beginning was a little slow but whe you are starting to get quests and your building massive armies it's awesome. For example i had an army of 60/60 all swordsmen, archers, catapults, and battering rams. I was super confident with this army lest to say because they had seen some fights all of the swordsmen were like lvl 10. But i got a little to confident and tried to seige a orc city and man i had no chance. I like the fact that i cant just jump in and seige the hardest city and expect to win. Right now im doing my best to improve my population and expand my power. It is definently a game with plenty of replay value because you can play as three different factions the Humans, Orcs, and Elfs. Right now having a blast with this game look foward to playing everday and completing more quests and becoming the strongest. Totally recommend this game for all strategy game fans!

reviewText:
This Game is one of a kind. You get to build your own medieval town or city whilst doing quests either in pvp, co op, or solo. You get to play as humans, orks or elf's, each have there own unique way of building cities and armies. You can recruit armies of darwfs and summon dragons to you aid.

If your into big fights on a large scale with pvp or pve with 1000+ armies on each side battling for gold, crowns,  power and land, this is the game for you. Its a fun medieval game just waiting to be conquered.

It's not all about the war though, you have to use your mind and skill to build your empire. You need to upgrade the armor on your troops for better defense in battle. You can also upgrade your sheep or cows for more milk and wool to trade for any resources you may need.  You can upgrade the tools the workers use and the clothes that they wear so they work faster and it improves the quality of materials they produce.

With every great army theres a great leader chose your hero, build your empire and destroy your rivals.

reviewText:
This is a really entertainment game i literally spend the whole weekend playing it. i one of the ones who bought it before it went free to play and the truth is that i quit it for a while due the lack of content and lag on the co-ops and pvp. then last week i decide to come back and see what was new and i find my self spending 12+ hours playing it :/ .

the new contents are amazing, game play still need some work,  specially the co-ops. i have seen my self helping PPL on a sage and then from no where i see they stop attacking or that im the only one doing it,  and when i ask them in the battle chat they say that they are actually already inside or waiting on me. so i guess that's a bug on the co-op that they need to work on. co-op should be helping each other trough strats to get the difficult objectives,  like those long sages.

the other thing is that they should consider the fact that not everyone is willing to PvP all the time, maybe its a way for them to force ppl buy shields to have some peace while playing,  but overall its really annoying and i consider that there should be better ways like other F2P game does to get cash like skins, and customization for your armies and stuff instead of forcing ppl buying shields, that will push some players away.

another thing that maybe they should work on is the AI of the armies when on battle some time i just don't know wth they doing out there lol. i need to cancel and re assign objectives all the time before they get killed.

ill still give this game a 4/5 maybe when they work a little bit more on it ill give them 5 :)

reviewText:
I've very much enjoyed this game.  I chose to go Elves, and much like another review I read some time ago they have a very Protoss-esque feel to them.  Their units are individually stronger than all the others, however they train slower and cost more.  Their buildings also give great benefits, yet generally seem to be on the fairly costly side.

Yet the cost usually isn't an issue as their economy is entirely trickle based, well actually it's mostly trickle based, the single glaring and strange exception to this is stone.  The lack of any way other than through alchemy or manual mining to get stone is honestly a pretty big issue, especially since I've been getting a resource boost already and was only making about 4 stone per minute if I didn't use alchemy - contrast that to the ten food per minute and the 25+ wood per minute.

The balance of resource gathering, at least for Elves, is off.  You have a resource cap, however most of your resources are going to be wood considering it takes zero effort to get lumber as an Elf.  As a matter of fact you start off the game getting 10+ wood per minute, compared to the paltry sums of about 1 to 3 per minute of everything else.

Despite that issue the game was absolutely still worth trying and playing and, for those looking for a slower-paced gameplay or an RTS that didn't take up all your time, the Elves would have been right up your alley.

The main benefit of the Elves, I feel, is the ability to log off of the game and come back some hours later to build your buildings and military up.  As resources continue to trickle in whether or not you're logged on it feels like a game that doesn't force you to pay attention to it every waking second of every day in order to progress, which, honestly, was a breath of fresh air.

Furthermore it's really nice not to have to worry about being attacked while logged off, unlike some games.  While it's a little clunky and has a few issues every once in a while the dev team is very active and clearly working hard to bring the best experience they can.  In such I really do suggest trying this game out if you're in the market for a fantasy RTSMMO.

reviewText:
Archers ready! Hold! Loose!
Swords, form sheild wall! Advance!
Archers Loose!
Rams forward!
Incoming enemy cavalry charge! Pikeman brace for impact!

Peasants get looting!

You get the idea... Control of your army is all yours. There is more than mentioned above, i just didnt want to give away to much :) Get in the game and play, you wont regret it.

Great stratagy game, well thought out design. More importantly you dont need to spend money to get a strong city, military and economy.

3 races to choose from (there is rumor of a fourth)
Great stories.
Wide range of troops opening a wide range of strategies. You control the strategy.
Friendly Devs and moderators all of which play the game with you.

Strongly recommend this game. enough wasting time on a review i need to get back to my army and order some peasants to upgrade my walls.

reviewText:
Kingdom Wars... Something I've been looking for, for a long time. It's quick, fast paced, and full of action. Lacking in a few departments though, as outlined below (for now.. maybe they'll update.)

Remember Warcraft? Starcraft? The strategy it took? yet how short the games were?  Well this is a persistant version which will span the eons~!  This game, putting strategy to 11, and action to 12. Kingdom wars is my personal new addiction.. My girlfriend says I should stop playing it, after putting in over 60 hours in less than 5 days! The up-to-date graphics and the strategy. It's all wonderful..




Here is some things they could add to make the game much better:

Add a Formation setup" option for pre-battle
date: so the troops are already set up the way you want instead of some weird star
recommended: or all mashed together.. it makes it difficult to grab the troops you want.  Or just a "formation setup" in the choices on the world map for the armies. like where it says "Transfer" "Camp" "split army" etc..\n\nHave seperate tabs for troop types when they exceed the maximum "select all"
hoursPlayed: or preset saved tabs for number keys
voteText: instead of having to reset them every battle. for an example.. (i don't know the max 'select all' option)  Say the max was 10 for example.. and you have 15 of said troop in your army. when you click the tab for knights
helpfulPercent: 5 would be not selected. Have a seperate tab for those extras.\n\nAuto trade routes.  for instance
votesHelpful: setup where you can set an army on the world map to go to a certain town
votesTotal: trade
votesFunny: for gold
commentsCount: and return home automatically.\n\nPre-battle map spawn choices. When you join someone in a coop battle
column16: both players troops are all mashed together
column17: and we spend 5-10 minutes just seperating them and setting them up. reviewText: Hands down one of the best games i've played in the past 5 years.  It's very addictive and captivating.  I like the 24 hour grace period that allows a new player to get used to the game and learn how to play before becoming a target for the rest of the online world.  And i like that everyone is pretty much on even ground.  You can't buy yourself in to the top like a lot of games online nowadays.  If i didnt have to work to support my family, i'm pretty sure i would focus about 80% of my time to this game, and my wife would probably divorce me.  I highly recommend this game to anyone and everyone.
voteText: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This game, as slow paced as it is, has to have been one of my more favorite RTS games. I've played plenty of Warcraft in my lifetime, but this, even with its low graphics and complicated play style, has been very fun. The co-op missions were also a great way for me and my friend to set goals in the game, since it gets harder with a friend than by yourself. With the races, humans have to be the most balanced between resource gathering and troop building, elves are easier to being able to build but harder to gather food to build an army, and orcs are the zerg of the three races with troop-making being a lot easier. I recommend this game for anyone curious to play a RTSMMO.
voteText: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A game so badly balanced thats its no surprise no one plays anymore
A small newbie army can easily face four dragons 1 hydra and a wizard in the pvp range of 550 points
(a  common newbie army) the elites wil be mid level at that and walk all over any other army
never seen  such bad balance or complete  lack of it as is the case here

The sieges themselves are great fun for a short while, but  with no end  game content at all its hard to see many stopping long other than for pvp( and see above for that)
Theres no alliance wars, not even race wars or any content for group play, like  a race related city to build up for race wide buffs

In other bug  news
your as likely to lose units to bugs as the ai or pvp, even your city isnt safe just in last week at least 4 in chat have said  thier entire city was lost to bugs
Units often instant die for  no apparant reason in  both pvp and  pve
The servers casue massive out of sync issues and that isnt new, I put a lot of time into the game before it went  f2p and we were forced to use steam to play and out of sync was really common even two years ago
The game has some great ideas, the combat system is fine other than terrible balance, but the bugs and flawed pvp make the game unplayable for me most of the time
play for a week or two for the pve side then move on to a proper game
If game is still in this state  four years after launch its hard to see it improvng much now

reviewText:
I actually bought the game back in the day, stumbling upon it during a massive sale. At the time, I wasn't particularly impressed, as it lacked a lot of the freedom of your typical city-builder, and the progress seemed slow enough that I wondered if I'd ever see my town grow into a city before losing interest in the game.

In retrospect, I think I had largely missed the point.

As it has gone free-to-play, firstly, I'm glad it avoided the pittfalls of becoming a pay-to-win game in the process, as the two more often than not go hand-in-hand. My town is still small and undeveloped, and as more of a city-builder myself, I have yet to really go deep into the siege/warfare aspects of the game. The controls for that, in what little of it I have engaged in, were a little clunky and troops were difficult to manage, but it seemed that it was surmountable, and that with time and experience, one could probably master the warfare system, should they be inclined to do so.

As a city-builder, which is where I'm coming from, it is a bit limited, as you don't really choose where buildings go as freely as you do in most others. That said. it has been fun seeing my town grow, and stocking it with a large enough garrison to defend myself against any potential attackers. In fact, the game is probably more comparable to an online game I used to play called Travian, but it is very polished graphically in comparison, and much deeper in terms of variability and different units/buildings.

The slow pace of the game might deter some, but I've come to enjoy stopping by every so often to see how many resources my villagers have accumulated. I check in once every other night or so, and in that span they've usually cobbled together enough stuff for me to be able to signifiantly add to my town with each log in.

All-in-all, it's not a game for everyone, and it limits the freedom of both the city-builder and the strategy/siege models, however in return it provides both of those in one game, doing something unique and playable, to me anyway. There's a lot in here for one game, and not necessarily too much, as is so often the case these days.

The price is right, these days, so it's certainly worth giving a shot, and remember to log in a few times before giving up on it, if you're not enjoying it so much. It wasn't until my fifth login or so that I started realizing that I was actually having fun with the game. Be that a critique or not, I recommend the game as it currently stands.

reviewText:
Now color me surprised when i find out there is a FTP MMO RTS that does not take after facebooks track history of special in-game currency that only money provides, color me when more suprised when it turns out to be a game remarkably simular to my childhood favorite Age of Empires.

Kingdom Wars is a MMO base builder Real time stratagy game that takes after Age of empires. It takes you into a wonderfully colorfull and well groomed fantasy land that is gorgouse to look at the more you adventure. Aside from Peasents and their endless offers of potato's you'll find a colorfull collection of unit types and specials that all races can use.

Thats right. you can be a human race, and have elven archers with orc brutes as your spearhead force. Whats more cool then that?

Oh right DRAGONS!!! You Can Have Dragons at your beck and call!!

Kingdom Wars brings to life THE entire fantasy adventure, dwarfs, elves, giant treeents, rampaging warg packs, ogres minotaurs and more await you in this well packed game. And its all Free to play. Additionally you can enjoy the entire game without having to spend money into it. Not that the fancy customization options wont tempt you.

As this is still a growing game, there are to be expected issues here and there, but with a lively staff, and friendly active in-game moderators anything that does happen can be worked out and solved so you can return to rasing your kingdom and adventuring across the world.

reviewText:
Having grown up with the Stronghold series, this is a must try for anyone following in similar footsteps.
There are several features that I love from Kingdom Wars that gives it that little boost:

Firstly Resources are gathered when you are both on and offline which help greatly, especially when you are trying to raise funds to buy crowns.

Decent F2P Model. While there are always the Cape-Crusaders who will nitpick at every F2P and say how P2W it is, even though they aren’t, KWs is a Play to Win as opposed to Pay to Win. While there are of course boosts and the ‘premium’ currency, all of this is earned in game and is rather pay for convenience.

And one of the best things I have seen on here is the fantastic moderator team they have in game. There never seems to be a question too trivial for them and they are willing to go to the ends of the earth to help you or give you direct link with someone who can.

reviewText:
Not a free to play - This is not a free to play game, and it is easy to see that it is not. Most games that are MMO city builders like this rely heavily on users buying boosters. This games does not. First of all, there are only three boosters in the game, and you can not use more than 1 of them per in-game account/city. The boosters that are there give you resources that are helpful to a beginner, but if you build your city up a bit, they can easily be aquired.

PvP - When I first started, I was afraid of going into the PvP part of the game. I was afraid that people who have already made giant cities and huge armies could walk in and take all of my things; this is definitely not the case. They have balanced the game enough so that you can only fight people within 10% of your army strength. 10% is so little, that it makes you rely only on good tactics. It makes EVERY siege/co-op/defence really fun and actually a really good match. Also, most of the online playing is co-op, which is honestly one of the most fun parts of the game. You can raid AI cities or do quests with your friends, and it makes the gameplay really fun, without getting completely screwed over. Also, if you REALLY do not like PvP, you can buy the single player campaign for only $1.99, which is honestly a good deal for how fun this game is.

Building your city - It is hard to build your city at the start, since resources are scarce. This is the point where the co-op takes place and is a big help. You can do quests with your friends and fight armies, and take all of the resources off of their cold dead bodies. This part beats every other city builder into dust. You can actually command your armies, instead of it being auto resolved for you. The game features 3 different races: humans, elves, and orcs. Each race is very balanced, and it would be a very hard decision on if you were to ask which race was the best. This lets you face other online players (or play WITH them) without worrying that their units are SOO much better than yours.

Raiding cities - Later on, once you have a big and tough army, you can start raiding AI cities. There are 30 (from my knowledge) cities that you can siege and either loot or make your vassel. Looting can be helpful, and gives you a lot of resources; while vassels give you resources over time.

Do not be turned away because it is an online city builder. Most of this game is co-op, instead of facing other players. You can join a clan and help each other out by sending each other resources. My in-game name is Enki, for anyone who has any more questions or wants to raid some AI with me! :)

reviewText: I would like to start off by saying that I am a big RTS\RPG fan.  I am also a big fan of ♥♥♥♥♥♥mes.  I have played this game with an open mind, as I suggest anyone else who tries this game, do without having any pre-conceived ideas or expectations.  The game mechanics are very user-friendly and easy to become accostumed to.  I have read many comments regarding the graphics.  Being an older gamer (over 40) I found myself getting a little nostalgic, which I really liked.  The game is excellent.  The concept is great.  The experience is one of the best I have had.  The most appealing aspect of this game, in my opinion, is that it is Free-To-Play.  Keep in mind that it is a RTS game and it will take time to do all the great stuff there is to do in this game.  So without further ado, good luck building your Kingdom and forging your Empire!

reviewText:
Everything I want, Nothing I don't  Kingdom Wars is a melting pot of different styles of games and game elements/mechanics. I personally view it as a Stronghold Crusaders + a dash of Total War + World of Warcraft (the RTS, not the MMO) + A strong influence of the game elements/mechanics of those web browser based games where you build a base and army and attack other people, get attacked etc. etc. I'm sure someone will correct me on the abreviation for that kind of game but I cant remember right now.

Now here are some  VERY IMPORTANT  distinctions from the rest of those games that I and many people have been asking and looking for but have never found with other games similar to this one.

The developers built into the game features that actually prevent a P2W environment!
For example there is absolutely no 'Low Energy! Come back tomorrow... OR pay us $5-$10-$20-$50(best BS deal!) to keep playing!' because  there is no energy.
You cannot be attacked or attack players of higher or lower level (premium units? stronger opponents!) and  you cannot be attacked while offline!   Finally, thank you!
Waiting for resources to gather and/or something to finish building and feel like there's nothing more to do in town? Make an army and go fight NPC/AI on the world map for gold and then use your spoils of war to buy those resources or even new units! Oh did i mention this is a great way to level up your units at the same time?
Or just log off and go live your life and come back to find the resources collected while you were offline!
Yes there is 'premium' currency  but  it is  reasonably and realisticly  obtainable in-game for your time + effort for free! Quest's and NPC/AI battle's being the best way I've found persoanlly.
An actually entertaining story line.
A suprisingly indepth and well made system for selecting your race, skills, and city location(s).
Single player  modes including campaign, seige, and seige defence.  You do have to pay $2 to unlock each of these modes however.  Personally this is not an issue for me as I don't plan on using single player mode, however it could be very useful to try out different seige strategies and really $2-$6 for this game is a ridiculously good deal considering some of the alpha games on here that cost $15 in the  hope  that they turn out good.
Predetermined building locations make your city(s) astheticly pleasing, strategically challenging and easy to build! None of that layers and layers of wall's shinanigans like every one of those crappy web-based Base Building RTSMMO's
Wow those first five elements are  exactly what people have been asking for in games similar to this for years.  That is a  huge  reason I like this game. Now I can feel satisfied that I finally found a good game out there where the developers/owner(s)/publisher actually give a **** about what me, the player, wants in a game rather than how much money is on the paycheck. From the bottom of my heart,  thank you  and I hope you cotinue building the game like this while keeping the same ideals!

You know what's even better? If you actually do spend money on the game, lets say you buy a dragon for your army,  they protect your investment.  While your normal units disappear forever when they die, your premium units, like the dragon you bought, only get knocked out and lose a few levels. Oh and you can't make an army of just dragons because that would be P2W plus they can still be countered and defeated by a prepared player, there's a dragon slayer i got for  free  after all. Right off the bat they are giving me a unit that counters one of the stronger units in the game! To make it even more balanced there's a unit cap, each unit takes up a certain amount of space, so you have to choose what you bring to battle wisely, a small but individually strong group of heavy hitters? Perhaps a massive amount of inexpensive foot soldiers with archers? It's all about the strategy, not who had the larger wallet.

Also you wanna know something awesome the premium days you can buy in this game? You choose which days you want to use them for. How many games can you think of that actually do that for their players? Personally i don't know a single one, because money. Now for the other side of the coin, this game has flaws as all games natuarlly do.

Animations are decent, but not great. Yes things still take time to build but it's not ridiculous amounts (i.e. 5-7 days). You have to pay for extra cities (gotta make money somehow so this is perfectly reasonable and fine with me). The controls can't be customized and are a bit clunky, biggest issue for me personally is the right mouse button. It controls your units  but  it also moves the camera if you have a single unit selected, very annoying esspecially when your trying to moe just your hero. plus there's is a very noticeable delay between the click and the effect (at least for me on my laptop). Then sometimes nothing happens at all. Trying to organize and manage your units is awkward and needs to be streamed lined. Especially when you have to do it quickly (Very Frustrating). Not to mention you have to indiviually select units to activate their abilites/magic/skills/powers which is very hard when they are in combat.

Theres also some minor graphical errors, especially when the weather changes and in a couple of cut scene's where the character(s) slowly turns invisible and OHMYGODTHEIREYESANDMOUTH! Personally I find that last type of glitch hilarious as it's actually pretty common in a lot of games. Upgrades and improvements of any and all kind require 'premium' currency, walls for example require an especially large ammount and you have 4 different one's to build, but like i said about premium currency, it is obtainable in-game for a reasonable amout of time and effort so a somewhat moot point.

Still I love this game and plan on continuing to play it for quite some time at a casual level, kill some time here and there, build this and that, do a quest here and there. This is a game that easily works with how you play games, hard-core, casual, it dosen't matter because it caters to any type of play style. I have only been playing for 9.3 hrs at the time of this writing but i can already feel that within 30-45 days, I will have an impressive city and army to boot and will be knocking down a few peoples walls!

I absolutely, highly recommend this game for people looking for a RTSMMO with RPG elements that lets you play at your own pace, your own schedule, your own style, your own budget and actually rewards you if you dont want to play all-day-everyday and throw money at it. Even if you do throw money at it it still goes  far beyond  what any other game I have played or known will do for you for your investment.

See you on the battle field and if you attack me, you shall feel the power and dismay of my elven arrows and Magical superiority!

This review helpful in anyway? Let me know below by leaving a comment and/or give a thumbs up and/or down.
